episodes.title: Kathy Jones
episodes.postBody:
In 1969, 12-year-old Kathy Jones left her home in Nashville's Woodbine neighborhood to go roller skating. Two days later she was found dead. We go in-depth on this tragic cold case.

UPDATE 7/21/19:

We've pulled our Kathy Jones episodes from the feed from the time being. In 2019, Olivia released an investigative podcast series on Kathy's murder called Flatrock. Check out flatrockpod.com for more info and take a look at the short trailer below.

episodes.title: Hey, I'm another episode
episodes.postBody:
Do you like Phil Collins? I've been a big Genesis fan ever since the release of their 1980 album, Duke. Before that, I really didn't understand any of their work. Too artsy, too intellectual. It was on Duke where Phil Collins' presence became more apparent. I think Invisible Touch was the group's undisputed masterpiece. It's an epic meditation on intangibility. At the same time, it deepens and enriches the meaning of the preceding three albums.

Listen to the brilliant ensemble playing of Banks, Collins and Rutherford. You can practically hear every nuance of every instrument.

In terms of lyrical craftsmanship, the sheer songwriting, this album hits a new peak of professionalism.
episodes.sources:
• Willard, Michelle. “Rutherford County: John Doe.”Middle Tennessee Mysteries, 22 Jan. 2018.
  • Wisuri, Jim. “Autopsy Offers Clues to Slain Man's Identity.” The Tennessean, 3 Aug. 1978, p. 19. newspapers.com.
  • ---. “Probe Continues Of Burned Body Found by Lake.” The Tennessean, 2 Aug. 1978, p. 15. newspapers.com.
